Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Neotoma Paleoecology Database, Community-led Cyberinfrastructure for Global Change Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Division of Earth Sciences Geoinformatics collaborative award supports continued development of Neotoma, a web-accessible centralized data clearinghouse for paleoecological data for which initial development support was provided by the EAR Geoinformatics Program (EAR- 0948652). This effort will enhance the current Neotoma platform by: 1) maximizing rates of data ingest through on-going data mobilization campaigns, recruitment and training of new data stewards, and development of facilitation software; 2) expanding the Neotoma data model to facilitate new proxy acquisition and secondary data including organic biomarkers, isotopic data from faunal specimens, and faunal taphonomic information; 3) developing new tools for data visualization and scientific exploration; 4) fostering engagement and growth of the Neotoma research community through support for a series of workshops intended to train data users, data stewards, and teachers, and by development of an on-line blog.

The Neotoma geoinformatics platform will promote integrative studies of the biotic impacts of climate change over the past five million years by allowing greater access to previously collected geoscience data sets of relevance and the tools to support analysis at marginal cost. The project will promote community engagement, support ease of data set ingestion, address PI team succession and promote educational module development. This award directly addresses OMB Memo M-13-13 ?Open Data Policy-Managing Information as an Asset.?

***

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Neotoma Paleoecology Database, Community-led Cyberinfrastructure for Global Change Research

subaward to B. Brandon Curry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (Illinois State Geological Survey, Prairie Research Institute)

Neotoma is a community-curated data resource that has become the standard repository for paleoecological data in North America and, increasingly, globally. By consolidating many kinds of paleoecological data into one centralized resource, Neotoma lowers costs of community-wide paleodata management while offering paleoecologists a high-quality, curated data resource. The specific contribution made in this subaward is for continental ostracodes, freshwater microorganisms common in modern lakes, ponds, estuaries, rivers, streams, and groudwater. Continental ostracodes also are abundant in the fossil record going back millions of years (but are most frequently used in records spanning the last 25,000 years or so). Ostracodes are useful for paleo-applications because they are sensitive to their aquatic environment including temperature, water depth, water chemistry, currents and other factors. Values of many of these environmental parameters are included in the database.

The ostracode database in Neotoma includes the presence or absence of about 110 freshwater ostracode species from North America (excluding Mexico). Ostracode and water samples were collected at the same time. Presently the Neotoma database holds records for more than 5,000 sites in Canada and United States.   

Major goals of the overall project include: 1) Entering new data into Neotoma, including the recruitment and training of new data entry people working under qualified Data Stewards, 2) Development of software or programs that expedites transfer of data from (older) existing formats to a Neotoma-friendly format, 3) Digital tool development for data visualization and scientific exploration,  and 4) Engagement and growth of the Neotoma research community through holding workshops intended to train data users, data stewards, and teachers. Within this framework, this subaward: 1) trained two data entry people (Caitlin Lebel and Andrew Anderson), and 2) developed a database translation tool, written in Python, to upload an existing database stored in Windows Excel to the Neotoma Paleoecologic Database (http://neotomadb.org).  We used this program to help upload 4549 records to the Neotoma database of ostracode paleoclimate field research sites in Canada (Caitlin was responsible for about ¼ of these sites; the rest were handled by another subaward to Alison Smith). The program, examples of program outcomes, and brief instructions are available through GitHub (https://github.com/NeotomaDB/xlsx2Tilia. B. Curry also participated in a short course on using GIS for making biogeographical maps at ISO 2018, and international meeting of ostracodologists held in Santa Barbara in August of 2018.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2019
Modified by: Ben B Curry
